text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Thursday.
- Collapse of Banca di Credito di Trieste could leave thousands of Croatian citizens living in Istria and Dalmatia without Italian pensions.
- Among Croatians listed as missing, there are still survivors kept secretly in Serbia's detention camps, says Manfred Nowak, representative of U.N. Human Rights Commission.
- Ministry of Tourism has presented A plan for tourism development on Prevlaka peninsula, still monitored by U.N. observers.
- Foreign investments in the past six years have totalled 1.8 billion German marks, of which 155 million account for contributions by Croatian diaspora.

- Serb leader in Eastern Slavonia Goran Hadzic promised a visiting Jewish delegation headed by Israeli ambassador to U.N. that all nationalised or confiscated Jewish property in the region would be returned to former owners.
- Opposition is to propose a bill on publishing information on income and property of public servants.
- The government will invest 1.3 billion kuna in restructuring of the railways system, says Zeljko Luzavec, Transport Minister.

- Banks may have saved Croatian tourism by granting loans to hoteliers when there were no tourists, but at times this could have been described as usury since their interest rates were very high, says Privatisation Minister Ivan Penic. -- Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
